review: I have had this thing for a couple weeks now and its okay. i feel like it could be better. most of the apps are useless if you arent a cable subscriber but it does allow me to get hulu on my tv finally (although the novelty of hulu is wearing off)the device doesnt work as well a it should. i was using my blu ray player for year to stream and it worked perfectly with no flaws. i decided to get this becaue youtube was no longer supported. i wish i could say it was a seamless transition.1. the remote it horrible. it top working ALL the time. you have to wiggle the batteries. a quick internet search told me it was a common problem so i  didnt exchange it. i changed the batteries. still does it. downloaded the remote app on my iphone, works a little better but kill my battery. remote i an issue.2. it does not have a sleep function, and if it is plugged in never turns off. no power button. the tv will stay on indefinitely if you forget to turn it off or fall asleep.3. it retarts itself more often than i think it should considering that my previous device never had a problem and wasnt even dedicated to just streaming.in all i feel like this was hyped up to be better than it is and i not perfected quality wise. for something that doe only one thing, i expect it to do it better. also any free content i found wa not worth the price of free, everything else is paid or inaccesible without expenive cable subscriptions. any channel i want i cant get. good for netflix and hulu if you subcribe. but so was my blu ray player and it was better.

review: The Roku stick was a good choice for us as a second option. We already had an Amazon Firestick (it made sense since we have Prime) but wanted to try the Roku stick as well.The stick itself works without flaw and my only constructive bit of criticism here would be for the intrerface. My husband and I are early 30s and very tech savvy, my parents not so much. We bought them one so they could cancel their cable and use Netflix or Hulu. Its taken about 6 months for them to fully commit to it because the interface is a lot of jumping around, adding channels, and screen changes to get it setup to your preferences--which was something to get used to from just changing channels up and down on a cable remote. Even then some "channels" represented themselves as free on the Roku stick but once downloaded required a subscription. You can imagine some of the frustration.So in all, I would say the Firestick would be better suited for those who are less tech savvy rather than the Roku stick. But the Roku stick is still a great product that works well and lived up to expectations.
